title: IEX stock exchange — of ‘Flash Boys’ fame — plans to exit listing business
text:
Startup IEX Group Inc. plans to exit from the cutthroat business of stock listings to focus on its bread-and-butter trading operations.

CEO Brad Katsuyama told MarketWatch during a recent interview that “listings became a business that was not our highest-opportunity business.”

IEX kicked off its listings unit, in which corporations pay fees to an exchange for services tied to being its primary trading venue, in 2017 after receiving approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission. That put the upstart trading company — made famous by Michael Lewis’s 2014 book “Flash Boys” — in head-to-head competition with heavyweights like Nasdaq Inc. NDAQ, +0.10% and the New York Stock Exchange, run by the Intercontinental Exchange Inc. ICE, +0.38%.

However, after Greenwich, Conn.-based online brokerage Interactive Brokers Group Inc. IBKR, +0.45% became IEX’s first listing about a year ago, the new exchange has struggled to woo other corporate executives to list shares on its venue and now believes that the costs associated with trying to attract new listings aren’t worth the effort. The Financial Times in a recent report, citing fundraising documents, said IEX had aimed to draw some 250 companies (paywall).

Interactive Brokers, founded by Wall Street trading icon Thomas Peterffy, will return to its original listing venue, Nasdaq, early next month, Katsuyama said, adding that Peterffy remains an advocate of IEX and its mission.

‘We knew the fight that we were getting into when we entered the exchange space on the listings side, it was a battle that ended up being a steeper hill than we thought.’ Brad Katsuyama

Founded about seven years ago, IEX has carved out a niche as a champion of the average investor and has advocated for fairness in trading on Wall Street exchanges. The company, heralded in the Lewis book, is perhaps best known for implementing a so-called speed bump on its exchange to thwart high-frequency traders, or HFTs, employing lightning-fast computers to make money from differences in stock prices on various trading venues and at various times throughout the trading day.

Katsuyama told MarketWatch that his interest in veering into the listing business was partly prompted by the attention his company had garnered from the Lewis book and the company’s desire to apply its speed-bump technology to other areas on Wall Street. However, the IEX CEO said, “the desire of an executive to want to change their listings didn’t translate” to companies switching trading venues. Katsuyama also said companies tend to require unanimous board-level approvals, not just a majority, which made it even more difficult.

“It was more challenging to get commitments than we thought,” he said.

“We knew the fight that we were getting into when we entered the exchange space on the listings side, it was a battle that ended up being a steeper hill than we thought,” Katsuyama said.

That said, the IEX founder said that the company’s core trading business remains very healthy and that the listings business represents 1/10th of 1% of its revenue.

“Our core trading business has grown to become the 8th-largest stock exchange company globally, trading more daily notional volume than the London Stock Exchange and the Toronto Stock Exchange,” he said.

The executive said he was happy with new ventures the company is set to launch, including an order type geared toward corporate buybacks. The exchange uses its proprietary technology, IEX Signal, to help companies repurchase shares without being front-run by enterprising HFTs.

Katsuyama told the FT in an interview this summer that he feels like many on Wall Street don’t want the company to succeed.

“People want us to fail. I think from that perspective we’re really proud of where we are, but there’s a lot more to do,” he told the paper then.

“The people who don’t like IEX are obviously going to take shots, but we think it’s a smart business decision,” Katsuyama told MarketWatch, regarding the decision to abandon listings.
